thread.title: Stocks edge higher in morning trading; GE jumps on earnings
thread.title_full: Stocks edge higher in morning trading; GE jumps on earnings

title: Stocks edge higher in morning trading; GE jumps on earnings
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Oct 16, 2015, 16:27 BST - UK Markets close in 3 mins. Stocks edge higher in morning trading; GE jumps on earnings US stocks edge mostly higher in early trading as investors pore over earnings news By Alex Veiga, AP Business Writer | Associated Press – 5 minutes ago View Photo 
FILE - In this July 6, 2015 file photo, an American flag is draped on the exterior of the New York Stock … 
U.S. stocks moved slightly higher in morning trading Friday, extending gains from the day before. Investors pored over the latest corporate earnings and economic news. The price of oil rose. 
KEEPING SCORE: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 35 points, or 0.2 percent, to 17,176 as of 11:15 a.m. Eastern time. The Standard & Poor's 500 index added four points, or 0.2 percent, to 2,028. The Nasdaq composite gained 12 points, or 0.3 percent, to 4,882. 
THE QUOTE: "People just want to get some comfort that the recovery in the developed markets is still intact," said David Lefkowitz, an executive director and equity strategist at UBS. "That in my mind is really the key question going into earnings season." 
PLAYTIME AGAIN: Mattel climbed 5 percent after an Oppenheimer analyst published a research note highlighting the toymaker's core brands as a bright spot. The report came a day after Mattel reported disappointing third-quarter results. Mattel was the biggest gainer in the S&P 500, adding $1.13 to $23.67. 
SURPASSED EXPECTATIONS: Industrial conglomerate General Electric reported a decline in third-quarter profit, but strong performances from its core units helped the company top Wall Street expectations. The stock added 49 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $28.53. 
CRIMPED CASINO: Wynn Resorts slumped 3.9 percent after the casino operator said new gambling regulations in Macau continued to hurt its business. The stock fell $2.86 to $70.90. 
ONLINE VIDEO PLAY: Shares in Alibaba rose 0.6 percent on news that the e-commerce giant has offered to buy up the rest of Chinese video streaming site Youku Tudou in a $3.6 billion deal. Alibaba gained 41 cents to $72.19. 
SECTOR VIEW: Seven of the 10 sectors in the S&P 500 were rising, led by consumer staples stocks, a category that includes Procter & Gamble and PepsiCo. The energy sector fell the most. 
MANUFACTURING REPORT: The Federal Reserve said that U.S. manufacturing production fell for the second straight month in September as factories cranked out fewer appliances, computers, and electronics. The decline suggests that a strong dollar, weak overseas economies, and cautious U.S. consumers are holding back factory output. 
MARKETS OVERSEAS: In Europe, the FTSE 100 index of leading British shares was up 0.4 percent, while Germany's DAX rose 0.2 percent. France's CAC 40 gained 0.4 percent. In Asia, South Korea's Kospi inched down 0.1 percent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose 0.8 percent. The Shanghai Composite in mainland China was up 1.6 percent. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 added 1.1 percent, aided by expectations that the country's central bank will come up with more stimulus measures this month or next. 
ENERGY: Benchmark U.S. crude added 3 cents to $46.41 in New York. Brent crude, used to price international oils, slipped 19 cents to $49.54. 
BONDS AND CURRENCIES: U.S. government bond prices fell slightly. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose to 2.03 percent from 2.02 percent. The euro was little changed at $1.1362 while the dollar edged up to 119.42 yen.
